newsitem.title: USA: U.S. debt fund managers extend duration -- survey.
newsitem.headline: U.S. debt fund managers extend duration -- survey.

text.p: Money managers extended duration in portfolio structures over the past week, but still remained significantly short duration exposure, according to a survey by Stone & McCarthy Research Associates.
"Last week, money managers were about as short as they get, on average, but have moved closer to flat since that time," the report said.
In the week ended May 6, the cash/assets ratio fell to 9.02 percent from 9.04 percent on an arithmetic basis and fell to 6.50 percent from 6.98 percent on a weighted basis.
The survey's actual/target duration index rose to 97.73 percent from 95.74 percent on an arithmetic basis and increased to 98.10 percent from 97.04 percent on a weighted basis.
Duration refers to a portfolio's average maturity and is used by portfolio managers to calculate exposure to risk.
The survey's bear/bull index advanced to 4.84 from 4.63 on an arithmetic basis. It slipped to 4.80 from 4.87 on an asset-weighted basis.
A number above 5.00 is seen as indicating investors are mostly long on the market.
Twelve percent of the portfolio managers polled said they were planning to be active in the coming week, up from eight percent the week before.
The bear/bull index collected among those intending to be active decreased to 4.67 from 5.00.
The Stone & McCarthy survey is conducted by the research firm weekly. It includes 25 market participants with total assets of about $100 billion, the firm said.
* Table provided by Stone and McCarthy Research Associates.
** Respondents intending to adjust portfolio in coming week.
